Spent the morning at Horseferry Road among other things trying to finalise arrangements for my treatment at Hospital. In afternoon called on Miss Cowlishaw at Inverness Terrace. She is still far from strong as a result of her recent illness and operation. Arranged to visit Cambridge.

Tuesday 22nd October

Spent the morning at Horseferry Road area making purchases at Army & Navy Stores. Stayed in during afternoon and evening.

Wednesday 23rd October

Left for Senior Staff Course, Cambridge to which body I am to lecture. Provided with quarters at Caius College.

Thursday 24th October

In morning prepared map illustrating advance from Cappy to Mt. St. Quentin and lectured on the operation. It appeared to be appreciated. In afternoon under the guidance of the Bursar of Caius College visited all the College of the University and Kings College Chapel. All exceedingly interesting. A Autumn – the colouring of foliage is magnificent. Returned to London at night. Found letter from France awaiting me, informing me that I had been awarded the French Croix de Guerre for services before in July. Translation of Army order published by Gen. Debeney 1st French Army follows:-

Entry.1142: Spent the day making calls in London. Saw Admiral Howarth Booth, A.G. Sharp, Mr. Larcombe, now graded as a Major of Comforts Fund, and Army & Navy Stores. Longstaff the portrait painter is to do a picture of me, and accordingly sittings to him are to be arranged commencing tomorrow.
Entry.1143:
Walked through Regents Park to the Longstaffs and spent the morning sitting to him.

At night went to theatre at night with Major & Mrs. Resborough. Saw Pigeon Post.
Entry.1144: Writing letters all the morning. In afternoon visited Regents Park and later to tea at Waldorf Hotel. Bitterly cold day. Squirrels at Regents Park very entertaining.
Entry.1145: At St. Bartholmews Hospital arranging for electrical treatment for arm. Decided to have it done at No. 1 General Hospital, Camberwell. Sent subscription to RVIA Melbourne. Dined with Major & Mrs. Grieg at Grosvenor Hotel and afterwards to Theatre – Colliseum – Russian Ballet Dancing particularly good.
Entry.1146:
Spent morning sitting to Longstaff.

Lunched with Miss Butler George at Piccadilly Hotel and during afternoon she took me to Bond Street Galleries. Called at Garrards Albemarle Street for my CB insignia left many months since for alteration.
Entry.1147:
Had photo taken at Elliott & Fry, Baker Street then went on to give Longstaff a sitting.

In afternoon attended Cinema show at Harrard Hotel, 2 Norfolk St., subject "With the Australians in Palestine". Met Mr. Larcombe & Henley there.
Entry.1148: In morning visited No. 1 London General Hospital at Camberwell, Horseferry Road providing me with car. Had both electric and massage treatment. In afternoon gave sitting to Longstaff.
Entry.1149: Stayed in during morning. In afternoon at offices of Ministry of Information, Norfolk Street, lectured to Press representatives of British Empire, America, Canada etc., regarding Australia’s effort in this war.
Entry.1150: At bank in morning and did sundry shopping. In evening took Miss Cowlishaw to dinner at Piccadilly Hotel. Discussed many items of Australian interest particularly as regards her brother Walter, and his non service with the A.I.F.
Entry.1151:
It has been decided that the 2nd Australian Division shall erect a monument on Mt. St. Quentin so while in London I wish to make preliminary arrangements.

Today Miss Butler George took me to a first class Australian Sculptor – Mr. Web Gilbert, and with him discussed details of such a monument. He is to prepare a sketch for me to see.
Entry.1152: At Camberwell Hospital in morning and sitting to Mr. Longstaff in afternoon. Wet miserable day.
Entry.1153: At Camberwell Hospital in morning. In afternoon left for Bradford. John and Edith met me at Station. Spent a very pleasant evening with them. Sisters all came to dinner.
Entry.1154:
With Edith visited Art Gallery in morning. A fine building well cited. In afternoon met Mr. Arnold and he later took us over his mill. Very interesting indeed.

Dined at Chesham park – all families being present. Mr. Sudders of Birmingham also called and I arranged to go with him tomorrow to his home.
Entry.1155: With Mr. Sudders left Bradford at noon for Birmingham. Motored out to Harborne and met Mrs. Sudders and family including Margaret (Mrs. George Halford). Had a very pleasant evening.
Entry.1156:
With Major Greg inspected his works, the Metropolitan Carriage and works. They have for some time been building tanks and Handley Page Aeroplanes. I spent a most interesting and profitable morning. Lunched with the Director at the works and in afternoon Major Greg arranged for me to inspect the British small arms factory. He accompanied me.

These works are particularly interesting especially the part allotted to the manufacture of Lewis guns. Returned to London.
Entry.1157:
Saw the Lord Mayor’s Show. By far the best display that has ever been made. The military display was particularly good and included much captured material. Overhead were airships and aeroplanes of all types and sizes. Left for Grand Fleet at 10.30 PM from Kings Cross Station.

Sunday 10th November

A miserable wet morning. Arrived Edinburgh 8 AM. Charley telephoned me from Charlestown giving me necessary directions. Took taxi from Edinburgh to Dalmeny. A picket boat from H.M.S. Queen Elizabeth took me over to north bank of Forth, where a car from RAF was awaiting me. Motored to Charlestown where I met Charley. He is looking extremely well, but has not grown as much as I had expected.

Lunched at Elgin Hotel and remained there during the afternoon for a heavy sea was running and the wind terrific. Towards evening finer weather eventuated and at 7.30 PM we went off to HMAS Melbourne in the ship’s steam boat. I met the Capt. (Capt. Ashley Rushton) and a number of his officers on this boat. The journey was so rough across to the ship, that I feared I should be ill, but however succeeded in controlling myself till ship was reached. Charley handed me over his cabin and he himself took over the Captain’s Sea Cabin. Dined with Captain, Commander and Charley.

Monday 11th November

Attended Divisions and later inspected ship. It has been arranged that I breakfast with the Captain and take other meals with Charley in the Ward room.

Message received that Armistice signed at 11 AM. Commander in Chief Admiral Beatty signalled the whole fleet and gave orders that at 7 PM the main brace should be spliced, in other words that a double ration of rum should be issued.

Called on C in C in morning on his Flagship HMS "Queen Elizabeth". Met old friends there in Commander Brand (Commander of the Fleet)

and Capt. Tweedie Commander of Destroyers. Went ashore in afternoon with Charley and called on Mrs. Williams at Dunfermline with whom we had afternoon tea. She is a daughter of Col. Sir James Burns of Parramatta, and her husband is a pal of Charley’s in HMAS "Melbourne". Returned to ship about 7.30. The main brace had been spliced, sirens were tooted, search lights playing and rockets being fired – a magnificent spectacle. It is said that the tooting of sirens was the result of the six toots of a vessel wishing to pass through the gates at Forth Bridge and which started off the whole Fleet.

Dinner on board at which officers attended from the other ships of the Squadron. A jolly night which I thoroughly enjoyed finished up at 11 PM We hear London has gone mad. During the morning the C in C had all his Admirals (23) to a Conference, and I understand dined with him at night.

Tuesday 12th November

On ship all day writing letters. Heavy fog during greater part of the day.

Wednesday 13th November

Stayed on ship all day. Again heavy fog. Received invitation from Admiral Halsey of the Australia for Charley and myself to lunch but came too late to accept. Dined with Capt. Dumaresq of ‘HMAS’ Sydney accompanied by Charley and afterwards attended an entertainment given by the ships Company. I said a few words to the assembly.

Thursday 14th November

Called on Admiral de Roebeck of HMS King George. Called on C in C, who kindly gave me the opportunity to go out tomorrow on HMS Calypso to meet German Admiral Meurer in the "Konisberg" who is coming to receive the terms of Armistice as they affect the handing over of German ships. Myself and artists etc. who are to go out tomorrow are to be on our respective allotted ships by 9 AM The dense fog persistently hanging over the Forth makes movement difficult.

Friday 15th November

Overnight instructions had been issued by 
 Staff of C in C
 S.O. 6th L.C. Squadron that "Agincourt" should provide picket boat to convey Surgeon Parker from "Agincourt" Lt. Freeman from "Erin" and Major General Rosenthal from "Melbourne" to "Caradoc", "Cassandra" and "Calypso" respectively. The officers concerned are to be placed on board their respective ships by 0900 today.

These instructions were based on the following wire issued by C in C G.F. on night 14th inst.

"S.O. 6 L.C.S. is requested to arrange for accommodation of following officers and ratings who should be on board ships detailed before 0900 tomorrow (Friday). Surg. Lieut. Parker from "Agincourt", Lt. Freeman RNUR from "Erin", Major Gibbon from "Malaya", CPO Smith and 1 rating from "Q.E.". Surg. Lieut. Parker is an artist, and Lt. Freeman and Major Gibbon are writers. C.P.O. Smith and 1 rating from "Q.E." will be employed on photographic duties and should be in "Cardiff". C in C GF has also given permission for Major General Rosenthal of Australian Army now staying in "Melbourne" to go out in Squadron".

At 7 AM picket boat from "Agincourt" came alongside "Melbourne" and took me on board. Then proceeded to various ships of 6th LCS already detailed and put off officers concerned. A dense fog hung over the Forth and the Middy in charge of our picket boat (by the way an Australian Middy from Jervis Bay) had great difficulty in finding the "Calypso" on which ship I had to embark. However just before 9 AM we succeeded in locating her and I went on board. I was met by the Capt. of the ship and his Officers and at once made to feel welcome.

Capt. Thorigen the Commander is a cousin of Lord Chelmsford, at one time Governor of NS.Wales.

At 9 AM the Captain assembled the ships Company on the quarter deck and informed them of the nature of the days duties. Guns were to be kept trained on the "Konisberg" when sighted. All were informed they might take what photos they wished and in writing to their friends and relatives were to be allowed to give details of the days work.

At 9.40 AM "Calypso" was under way in place as shown on adjoining diagram. The fog was intensely dense and remained so till well down the "Forth". After passing through the 3rd protecting boom we picked up 10 destroyers who accompanied us in formation as shown on opposite page. Sighted "Campania" wreck just before

Diagrams Illustrating Formations Of 6th L.C.S. Destroyers During Operations Relating To Meeting Of "Konisberg"
Entry.1158:
reaching Inch Reith. During a recent storm she had dragged her anchor and been in collision with a Man O’War being sunk as a result luckily without loss of life. She will be remembered as an old liner turned into an armed merchantman.

When open sea was reached direction was changed to the South and line formed as in second sketch on last page.

It had been arranged that Admiral Meurer in the "Konisberg" should be at a certain definite Rendezvous at 2 PM

At 1.40 PM our Squadron passed the appointed Rendezvous and
 At 1.40 PM received a wireless from "Konisberg" intimating that she was altering course in order to avoid a German Mine Field and that accordingly she would be late at her Rendezvous.

Captain Thorigen informed me the German mine field had been removed by our mine sweepers some 2 weeks earlier.

At 2 PM "Konisberg" was distant 20 miles.

Our ship passed Rendezvous line, then turned northward for about 30 minutes, again turned southward, and "Cardiff" picked up "Konisberg" at 3.23 PM. Up to the moment speculation had been rife as to whether "Konisberg" would really turn up, and now here she was. On "Calypso" there was a rush to the range finders to get the best possible view of the ship. All this time I had been with the Captain on his bridge.

"Cardiff" signalled to "Konisberg" "Follow me 21 Knots". All other ships of squadron and Destroyers then took Stations as on previous page and made for the Forth.

The "Konisberg" flew the Admiral’s flag at the foremast, a large white flag at the main mast, and the German ensign at the gaff.

She is a small looking craft, armed with 5.9.

Our guns were manned on sighting "Konisberg".

On arriving at the anchorage off Inch Reith "Cardiff" signalled "10 Knots", "stop", "Anchor".

A number of civilians were to be seen on board.

C in C wirelessed "You are requested to refrain from using Radio", and he also informed Admiral Meurer he did not wish to see Socialist delegates. German Admiral taken off in destroyer "Oak" at 6.34 PM and proceeded to Flagship of C in C Both "Konisberg" and our own ships brilliantly illuminated, now no need to "darken ship".

Admiral Meurer received on Flagship "Q.E." by Commodore of the Fleet the Hon. Brand (son of Viscount Hampden at one time Governor of N.S.W.)

and the Captain of the Q.E. and conducted below to the C in C The meeting was formal in the extreme strictly courteous but distinctly cold 
and
. Both bowed stiffly. The German Admiral so keenly felt his position that it was an appreciable time before he could speak but his ashen face clearly showed he felt his task to be a truly bitter one.

He and his staff were given a meal in Commodore Brands cabin. Some difficulty was occasioned in obtaining the necessary personnel to attend upon these officers. The meal consisted in the main of a leg of mutton, two bottles of Claret one of port, and other sundry articles and it is significant that at the conclusion of the meal nothing remained but empty bottles and the bare mutton bone.

The civilians who came over in the "Konisberg" lived on the mess deck. I got back to "Melbourne" about 11 PM.

From about 10.30 AM fog commenced to lift and by the time "Konisberg" was sighted the day was reasonably clear and a thoroughly good view was obtainable of the german cruiser. At night fog again settled down on the Forth.

Saturday 16th November

Dense fog all day hence confined to ship.

Sunday 17th November

My stay in "Melbourne" terminated and today I transferred to HMAS "Australia" flying the flag of Rear Admiral Halsey, commanding 2nd Battle Cruise Squadron. At night with Admiral Halsey dined with Vice Admiral de Roebeck on HMS "King George V". She is lying West of Forth Bridge while "Australia" is lying East – distance apart about 3 to 4 miles. Fog very dense, but we succeeded in reaching "King George" only about 20 minutes late. A very enjoyable dinner & met many old friends of Gallipoli days. After dinner saw a fine cinema show on board. On boarding the Admirals barge for the return journey the fun commenced. The fog was now denser than ever, but after much trouble we made the Forth Bridge not however the centre bay as intended but the most southerly bay. We knew our position however and the Admiral himself

controlled the helm. Judge of our surprise a little later when we thought we were well on our way to our ship on our Easterly course to find ourselves passing under the northern bay of the bridge, having come due north instead of East. The explanation lay in the fact that the steel work of the bridge affected the compass. Finally we reached the "New Zealand" the next ship to our own and thought we were now out of trouble. The next ship we located which we concluded as the "Australia" proved to be the "Barham" our course having been this time south instead of East. Again we tried to make the "Australia" but found ourselves back again to the "New Zealand". Our next attempt took us at last to the "Australia" at 1 AM having been 2 hours doing 3 to 4 miles.

Monday 18th November

Spent an interesting day in looking over the "Australia". The former Admiral (Admiral Levison) has made his apartments very interesting. He has collected Australian books, early experiences concerning early explorers, and recorded on the walls the doings of early navigators and the various flagships of the Australian Stations. At night dined with Admiral Levison now a Vice Admiral flying his flag on the "Barham". Here I met a retired naval officer Admiral Farquhar who is full of interesting incident and anecdote. We all after dinner visited the "Warsprite" and attended a most excellent Comic Opera performance of "The Time Machine", based on "The Merry Wives of Windsor. I thoroughly enjoyed the show.

Early in the day met Vice Admiral Napier.

Tuesday 19th November

Noted H.M.S. "Courageous" one of the British Ships" flying Vice Admiral NaPiers Flag. His Capt. (Capt. Bromley) showed me all over the ship. I was much interested in her. Her triple gun turrets were new to me, and her engine rooms too were full of interest. On this ship met Admiral Oliver.

Visited Admiral Phillimore on the "Furious", an aeroplane ship also full of interest and saw many new innovations including aeroplanes carrying torpedoes. At night Admiral Halsey

dined with the C in C and the other British Admirals with Admiral Rodman of U.S. Ship "New York". During the day visited the "New York" and was much struck with the great interest that is taken in the comfort and welfare of the men. Admiral Farquhar dined with me in the "Australia". German Fleet is to surrender on 21st inst. Mr. Murdock (an Australian pressman) and Mr. Preston are being accommodated on " Australia" and arrived tonight. Wired to London for an official artist to come aboard.

Wednesday 20th November

Today the King and Queen visited the Fleet. The King inspected the Fleet while the Queen visited Hospitals. During the morning I visited the "Ayres" a new aeroplane ship then went off to the new "Vendector" launched last October and from her deck or rather bridge saw the King move round the Fleet on the Destroyer Oak and added my cheer to those lustily given by Ships Companies. In the Vendector I met Capt. Grace who had served with us at Gallipoli. Admiral Phillimore lunched with us in "Australia". Official artist missed his train, but Col. Ironside of Corps HQrs. arrived and will witness tomorrow’s Ceremony. A number of Australian Soldiers (about 12) from all Divisions had persuaded the officer in charge of "Australia’s" picket boat at Forth Bridge to allow them to come on board to see some friends. On arrival they requested to be allowed to remain to see the surrender of German Fleet. The Commander promised to lay their request before the Admiral and advise them later. They however had heard I was on board so as a deputation they paraded before me asking me to use my influence with the Admiral. I did so and he at once agreed to let them remain so tomorrow they will be among the few soldiers who will see this great naval event. Fog is still very dense and heavy and present indications are not hopeful for observance of tomorrow’s pageant. Ship has been newly painted and will tomorrow fitly represent "Australia", the Sydney and Melbourne too will take part with their own Cruiser Squadron under Admiral Ferguson.

Thursday 21st November

This day is 
easily
 surely the greatest in the Naval History of the World, for the proud and boastful German Fleet has under its own steam and manned by its own officers and men arrived in British Waters and has 
handed
 surrendered itself 
over
 to the British Navy of glorious and stainless fame. Never was victory so complete and never humiliation so great. It was a proud privilege to watch this wonderful surrender especially as I saw it all from the Bridge of our own HMAS "Australia", which as leader of the 2nd Battle Cruiser Squadron and flying the Flag of Rear Admiral Halsey was well placed from a spectacular point of view. As a representative of the British and Australian Army together with other officers and men of the Australian Corps, I paid my tribute to the ceaseless watchfulness, bravery and daring of our own British tars and their ships.

At 3.10 AM "Australia" was under weigh. I came up on deck in case anything of interest could be seen. The most gratifying feature was the clearness of the morning. The fog had dispersed and it seemed as if Providence had specially vouchsafed a clear day for this dramatic scene of the supremacy of right over wrong.

Gradually ships took up their allotted Stations as shown on opposite page. Little could be seen of the Grand Fleet other than our own Squadron for the lines of ships 
 was
 were 6 miles apart. Several evolutions were performed prior to meeting the German Fleet.

Early in the afternoon the Cardiff was sighted leading the line of German ships and towing her observation balloon. The air service was represented by air ships and many aeroplanes. Unfortunately from the "Australia" only a local view could be obtained, the whole convoy covering as it did a depth of 20 miles. The German Flagship "Frederick der Grosse" together with "Konig Albert", "Kaiser" and "Kron Prinz William" could be clearly discerned but the remaining German ships were lost in the distance. The whole proud Fleet turned and took up Station as shown on sketch page 487 , escorting the German Fleet to Inch Reith where they were to anchor.

The 2nd BCS of which "Australia" is the Flag ship was detailed together with 1st B.S., 2nd Light C.S., 3rd Light C.S., and destroyers as detailed by Commodore Tweedie as guard over the German Fleet when anchored so during the afternoon our Squadron took up Station in rear.

Cruising Order When Approaching Rendezvous With German Ships Proceeding To Rosyth - For Internment.

While in process of so doing the whole German Fleet including Destroyers passed us, and the magnitude of the German Naval debacle was brought home to us in a most vivid manner.

The surrender involved 14 heavy ships, 7 Light Cruisers (names see sketch) and 50 destroyers of latest pattern from 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 6th & 7th Flotilla.

Just about dusk "Australia" came to anchor in her allotted place, the German ships having previously acted similarly.

Each ship in the Grand Fleet for this day flew 2 white ensigns, large new and clean, and in these flags lay the only token of jubilation in what was otherwise a stern and silent proceeding.

The formation of the German fleet can be seen in adjoining sketch, Battle Cruisers leading Light Cruisers 3 miles astern (all 3 cables apart), Destroyers as 5 groups 6 miles astern of L.C.s all single line ahead, Guns in securing position trained fore and aft.

The German vessels were business like craft but appeared much neglected. The "Emden" had the "Iron Cross" painted on her bows, an award from the Kaiser because of the exploits of her predecessor, destroyed by HMAS "Sydney" off the Cocos Islands in November 1914.

With the Grand Fleet was the "Amiral Aube" a French Man O’War representing the French Navy.

As ships other than those detailed for guard duties passed the C in C in Flag Ship Queen Elizabeth they gave him a raising cheer. In the evening a service of thanksgiving was held by Command of the C in C on his flag ship and he recommended the same course to be carried out by all Admirals, and naturally his wishes were carried out.

Admiral Halsey of "Australia" presented me with his flag flown on this memorable day and I shall keep it as a valued memento of the German surrender and in due course pass it on to my naval sons.

Left "Australia" at 6 PM, for Rosyth dock, calling on Admiral Levison in "Barham" and Admiral Robinson in "New York" on my way. Took train for London at 10.30 PM
Entry.1160: With Col. SoMerville arrived in London at 10.30 AM. Attended to correspondence during afternoon. Awarded French Legion d’Honneur.
Entry.1161: During the day called on Mr. Woodburn and Larcombe of Comforts fund. Met Sir Gregory Wade at their offices. Called at Bank & Australia House. In afternoon with Miss George called on Sculptor Web Gilbert over Mt. St. Quentin monument. He has designed a fine composition representing an Australian soldier bayonetting the German eagle. When I return to France will arrange finally for placing of the Commission.
Entry.1162: Miserable wet day and did not go out of room. Wrote letters.
Entry.1163: Attended at Camberwell hospital for the last time. At 11 AM met Mr. Larcombe and talked over Australian business matters. Lunched at Piccadilly Hotel with Col. & Mrs. Durrard & Miss George. The former gave me my French Croix de Guerre. After lunch with Miss George attended the opening of war picture display at Royal Art Society’s rooms. Many fine pictures and portraits, Longstaff’s sketch of myself included.
Entry.1164: Spent the day in final shopping. Wire received from Charley stating he would probably arrive in London next Thursday so I will defer my return to France till Friday.
Entry.1165: Again shopping etc. Selected and forwarded part song to Capt. Dumaresq of "Sydney" for his glee party. Great difficulty in obtaining films for camera. We are now allowed to take photos in the field.
Entry.1166: Very wet day, imprisoned in Hotel.
Entry.1167: Left Victoria Station for Folkestone at 11.35 PM. Left Folkestone about 2 PM and disembarked at Boulogne about 4 PM. Wet day – decided to remain at Hotel Folkestone for night. Pope ADC. met me. Had an interview with Gen. Monash. He is on his way to London having handed over the Corps to Gen. Hobbs and he himself is to be Director General of Demobilization. He briefly outlined what was intended to be done.
Entry.1168: Left Boulogne at 8 AM and travelled via Calais, Dunkerque, Furner, Mienport, Ostend, Zeebrugge, Bruges to Coutran which latter town we reached about 5 PM. Was very interested in Ostend (Vendector) and Zeebrugge Intrepid & phiginia where we saw the hulks of ships employed in the fine exploit of the Dover Patrol under Admiral Keyes in blocking the fairway. At Coutran met Interpreter de Witt of Belgian Mission who used to be with me in
Entry.1169: Brigade. His home is in Coutran, and we dined with him & his sister and later occupied billets allotted by Town Major.
Entry.1170:
Breakfasted with de Witt and we had a look at the town notably the Church and two old Towers flanking the Lys. Germans have done a good deal of damage, especially to bridges and roads. Left Coutrai at 10 AM and travelled via Turcoing, Roubaix, Lille, Douai, Cambrai, Le Cateau to our HQrs. at Cartignies.

At Lille called on Gen. Birdwood and saw Gen. White and Gen. Strauberger now MGRA. Lunched at Army HQrs. and met General Orth, Chief of Belgian Mission. King George today visited the Division before my arrival, Gen. Robertson acting as Divisional Commander. The Division has been in the area for a few days having previously spent 3 days at Bohain immediately after leaving Bellay.
Entry.1171:
At 9.45 AM called on Gen. Hobbs at Corps HQrs., Avesnes. At 11 AM motored to old battle fields at Montauban and Beaurevoir line. Then during afternoon we met the King at Belloner Farm accompanied by Gen. Rawlinson and personal staff. Gen. Charles of 25th Div., Gen. Jackson of 50th Div. and myself had to explain the operations of our various Divisions. The King was interested to hear how my arm was getting on, he remembered seeing me at Corps H. Qrs. at Bertangles when I had it in a sling in August last. Returned to HQrs. at 5 PM.

Called on General Martin at No. 61 CGS. He is critically ill with pneumonia, but today shows a slight improvement.

Col. Miles and Capt. Ware to mess area near Charleroi to finally fix Divisional HQrs.
Entry.1172:
Remained in office all day writing up diary and attending to private and official correspondence.

Miles & Wood returned from forward area. Gen. Martin improving.
Entry.1173:
Writing up diary and account of surrender of German Fleet. Met Brigadiers and CRA at 2.30 PM. Discussed proposal to erect 2nd Aus Div monument at Mt. St. Quentin. Unanimously approved and committee appointed to at once collect subscriptions. Cost will be £1000.

Thursday 5th December

Visited billets at Marcinelle near Charleroi. Travelled via Avesnes, Maubeuge & Mons to Charleroi and returned via Beaumont to Cartignies. People of Marcinelle very anxious to have us with them and they are giving us of their very best. All the

billets will be exceedingly comfortable. We had no time to look round the Mons battle field. That experience must come later. Gen. Godley and 22nd Corps HQrs. are in the town. Gen. Wisdom also today forward in new area.

Friday 6th December

During morning remained at DHQ and attended to correspondence etc. In afternoon attended Conference at Corps HQrs. Details concerning moves to new area, educational and trade proposals, etc., were discussed by Divisional Commanders with the Corps Commander. Informed that the Prince of Wales is to stay for some two weeks with the Australian Corps and wishes to meet officers and men.

Saturday 7th December

Left DHQ at 8 AM to visit Gen. Godley at Mons, & Army Commanders of 1st and 3rd Armies at Valenciennes & Cambrai respectively. Gen. Godley away on leave. Learned that 3rd and 4th Canadian Divisions are located in Mons. At 1st Army HQrs. saw General Alexander MGRA. Army Commander and MGGS both absent. Found that 3rd Army has moved to Flexicourt the old HQrs. of
Entry.1174: Army. From Cambrai came home via Bellicourt, St. Quentin and Bohain. Called on Gen. Martin at No. 61 CCS at Bohain. Found him very low indeed.
Entry.1175: Received wire from GHQ stating that Charley is being issued with permit for France from 10th to 18th inst. Lt. Pope took GOC
Entry.1176: Bde. to Boulogne. Mrs. Wisdom is ill and is to be operated upon. Wrote letters. Wet day.
Entry.1177:
Col. Miles going on leave to Parisand the Riviera. Took him to Parisby car via Vervins-Marle-Laon-Soissons-Villers Cotteret-and Meaux. Journey from Laon to Soissons along the Chemin de Daine exceedingly interesting. There are evidences of very severe fighting. Arrived Paris4.30 PM. Took rooms at Astrea Hotel, Rue Caumartin. Before dinner called on Madame Equer. Dined with Col. O’Connell of Base. Afternoon tea at Coro – dinner at Hotel. Parisilluminations much improved and streets thronged.

Tuesday 10th December

Left Paris at 8 AM and reached DHQ at 5 PM Travelled via Daumanter-Nanteuil-Crepy-Attechy-Chaucy-La Fere-Saues-La Capelle and Avesnes. Saw historical old Chateau at Pierrefond erected I understand by 
Napoleon
 Louis of Orleans in 1390 at great cost. Brought back with me Lts. Murray and Watson of 2nd DA. Chauny and La Fere much damaged by shell fire and country from to much intersected by trenches and wire and must have been the scene of heavy fighting. Charley due to cross Channel – GHQ permits have been supplied him. Gen. Martin showing slight improvement. I brought him some wine.
Entry.1178:
Received wire from Pope that Charley had not arrived at Boulogne. Wired Pope to wait for this evening’s boat. Col. MacKenzie returning to Australia came to see me. Arranging that he shall be sent off by car tomorrow direct to Boulogne. He told me of his period at the Base and feel he has been rather unfairly treated. Dined with us at night.

Thursday 12th 
October
 December

Inspected sample units of all three Brigade Groups Transport. A good many matters required attention before a uniform standard can be attained.

Capt. Bean who has been with 5th & 6th Bdes. completing his records of recent fighting lunched with us and later proceeded to
Entry.1179: Bde. Final honours for last battle (other than V.Cs.) awarded.
Entry.1181:
December

Inspected sample teams from units of Div Arty Very good turnout. Discussed with ADMS details concerning V.D. in Charleroi and measures to be taken to protect our men. Col. Crothers is to return to Australia, leaving tomorrow. 

Received word from A.I.F. HQrs. London that Charley is to arrive in Boulogne on
Entry.1182:
inst. Capt. Bayley returned from Nice.

Saturday 14th 
October
 December

In morning interviewed Company Commander (Major Charlton) and O.C. Trains with a driver who had a grievance.

Censured Major Charlton. Saw gunners Pring and Hordern. Addressed all officers of Division by Brigade & Artillery groups concerning Education, VD, Claims, etc. Received a big Australian mail. Pope returned from Boulogne.

Interviewed Col. Murphy and Major Harris re their visit to Charleroi and in connection with placing some of our men in local works for educational purposes. They met with much success. Details are to be arranged with our education officers.
Entry.1183: Visited Charleroi re educational matters. Went on to Waterloo. Made a cursory examination of historic farms etc. also Church etc. at Waterloo but will spend more time on inspection on a future occasion. Lunched with Gen. Aldercron Brigadier of 124th Brigade 41st Division and called on Gen. Lawford in afternoon. Found he was out, but met his CRA Gen. Cotton. On returning to DHQ found a wire from Capt. Wood saying he and Charley were stranded at Boulogne – car having broken down. Another car sent on for them.
Entry.1184: Spent the day in HQrs. writing letters. Capt. Wood and Charley arrived about 6.30 PM. Charley looking very well. Addressed all Brigade groups re several matters.
Entry.1185: Watched all three Brigade groups commence their march to new area. Infantry generally good. Machine Gun Corps (except 6th) indifferent. Many points brought to notice. Miserable day. Charley accompanied me.
Entry.1186: Again watched Brigade Groups marching through. A great improvement on yesterday’s show. Failed to see 7th Brigade Group. Artillery generally good, excepting DAC which was only fair. The 86th Brigade RAFA (Army Bde.) at present with us made a good show. Charley again accompanied me. Drizzling rain all day – very miserable for the troops.
Entry.1187:
Watched units of Division on the march. The Engineers (less 1 Coy.) and 22nd Battalion very good – also 7th Brigade group. Did not see 5th Brigade. Called at Corps HQrs. Saw General Hobbs now promoted Tempy. Lieut. General while commanding the Corps.

Took up quarters at Marcinelle, balance of DHQ having moved in during the day.
Entry.1188:
Made an official entry into Marcinelle at head of 28th Battalion. Dismissed parade on the Square in front of the Marie. Myself and staff also Brigadier of 9th Bde. and Col. Currie were welcomed by the Burgomaster in terms of the following 
translation
 address.

"General Rosenthal et vous tous Officiers

Au noue de l’Administration communale de Marcinelle je vous souhaite la plus cordial bienvenue:

Au lendemain de la liberation du territoire, nous avons eu l’honneur de recevoir ici meme des delegues autorises des grandes Armees Britanniques et Belges et de leur dire au nom de la population toute entiere notre admiration et notre reconnaissance pour les sacrifices consentis pas les nations alliees en favour de la Belgique oppremee.

Aujourd’hui Messieurs, que nous avons enfin recouvre notre liberte et notre independence, nous savons seulement apprecier les soufFrances morales et materielles que nous aurions du supporter si jamais la barbarie avait ete maitresse de ce pays.

Aussi, notre reconnaissance sera eternelle a la noble nation britannique qui n’a pas hesite a voler au secours de notre pays lorsqu’il fut brusquement envahi par ces barbares qui en avaient garanti la neutralite. En alors, nous avons assiste a ce spectacle a jamais inoubliable que l’Histoire avec nous rapportement a nos arrieres petits enfants: l’immense empire britannique mettant en oeuvre toutes ses resources au service de la civilisation avec sa flotte toujours Invincible les armees de tous les pays unis a l’empire.

S’il y eut une veritable emulation entre toutes ces Armees, L'Armee Australienne fut parmi celles qui ont conquis le plus de lauriers sur les glorieux champs de bataille. Deja malgre l’occupation et la censeuse boche nous avions appris pas des

journeaux intendits les actions d’eclat ete votre brillant Armee. Maintenant nous savons officiellement combien ces renseigements etaient en dessous de la realite. C’est pour cette raison que l’Administration communale de Marcinelle est fiere de recevoir aujourd’hui un des chefs de cette belle armee et de vous dire a vous, General, et aux brillants officiers sous vos ordres toute notre admiration pour votre bravure et les actes d’heroisme qui perpeteurent votre memoire et glorifieront votre pays.

Nous regrettons profondement que notre petite commune n’ait pas les ressources et les attraits qu’une ville presente pour recevoir dignement et avec tout l’eclat qu’elle merite une armee de heros qui s’est couverte d’artant de lauriers que L'Armee Australienne dans cette lutte gigantesque coutre la barbarie.

Mais croyez le bien General que notre reconnaissance et notre admiration n’en sont que plus profondes. J’ai la conviction que pendant votre trop court sejour parmi nous vous trouverez au sein de la population l’accueil le plus cordial et le plus fraternal. De son cote l’Administsration communale et les divers services communaux feront l’impossible pour vous donner toutes les facilities desirables.

En agissant ainsi nous savons que ces temoignages n’exprimeront qu’insuffisament toute la reconnaissance dout nous vous Sommes redevables.

C’est guide pas ces sentiments qu’au nom de l’Administration Communale je leve mon verre a vous, General, a vous, officiers d’elite, a la brillante Armee Australienne a la grande Armee britannique."

I made reply as follows:-

My dear Mr. Mayor and Gentlemen,

I deeply appreciate the honour you have shown to myself and my troops by thus welcoming us here today as representatives of the British Army, and expressing your thanks for what service has been rendered to Belgium.

We all realise what a debt of gratitude the whole world owes to the Courageous King of Belgium and his people, for was it not due to the splendid efforts of the Belgian Army in holding back the advancing German hordes that the British Divisions were able to take their places in the battle line in sufficient time to ward off disaster.

Great Britain has even been a Champion of right as against wrong, and her Dominions have ever and will ever rally round her in time of trouble.

We can fully sympathise with you in the troubles and sorrows you have suffered, but, thank God, the enemy has been decisively beaten and your country and France are both now free, free to reestablish your towns, your industries and your homes.

I am pleased to hear your reference to the British Navy. We shall never know just how much it has performed, but this we assuredly know, that but for its unceasing watchfulness the British Army could not have been maintained in Europe nor the American Army landed here.

I had the proud privilege recently of spending a short holiday with the Grand Fleet, and witnessed such a sight as I never expected to see, and certainly will never see again – the surrender of the German Fleet, the final admission of all of the superiority of the British Navy.

I thank you for your kindly references to our Australian Army. When war was first declared our country at once decided to give all the assistance possible and I think we may today fairly claim that the Australian troops have been of sterling value.

We have in the first place contributed a Battle Cruiser, 3 light Cruisers and several Destroyers, all of which are serving with the British Fleet. We have contributed over 350,000 men and 800 nurses who are distributed through all theatres of war. We have maintained 5 Divisions in Europe and 2 Mounted Divisions in Palestine – all voluntarily – and every penny of the cost is being borne by Australia.

We have fought in Egypt, Palestine, Gallipoli, France and Belgium. In your country we have taken part in much hard fighting notably at Messines and Passchendaele. It was my privilege to have at one time under my Command for a period of 3 months, six batteries of Belgian Field Artillery, and they always did their work most ably and gallantly.

Many brave lives have been lost, but we all feel that no sacrifice is too great to ensure our old time liberties being maintained.

The troops you see here to day represent but one battalion

of my 15,000 troops, which will be today established in the area to the south of Marcinelle.

In making our preliminary billetting arrangements we have already experienced the greatest kindness and I am quite sure our stay among you will be to us a very happy time indeed and a very pleasant change from our years of fighting.

While I am sure you will all welcome the day when all troops will quit your dwellings, yet I know you will appreciate the change of Australian soldiers for German, and we on our part will do all we can to reduce to a minimum the inconvenience our being in your midst must necessarily cause you.

Brother Australian officers I ask you to drink most heartily the health of the Burgomaster of Marcinelle and his Colleagues."

At the conclusion of the Ceremony two dear little girls presented me with flowers and made a sweet little speech.

All troops reported settled in their respective areas.
Entry.1189: Today we have had a most interesting run. Charley and Major MacCallum accompanied me. We left Charleroi in the early morning, passed through Namur and Liege to Spa and from Spa across country to Namur is beautiful and most interesting. Saw a number of Boche officers and men in Spa – not very punctillious about saluting. Saw a very interesting fort just south of Liege, one of those forming the defence of the City. Guns and emplacements had all been destroyed. Had afternoon tea at 4th Army HQrs.
Entry.1190:
Left in early morning with Charley & Major MacCallum for a journey through Waterloo to Louvain thence to Malines thence through Brussels to Charleroi. Visited Quatre Bras and all the buildings and points of interest at Waterloo, also took some photos. Called on a farmer near Quatre Bras and saw some fine specimens of Belgian draught horses. In Louvain we saw the mark of Hun incendiaries, the Cathedral and other buildings having been badly damaged by fire 10 days after the Boche occupation.

Here also we took some photos. Service being conducted in the Cathedral to the accompaniment of a very fine Military Band.

At Maline (a fine town with some fine buildings) had a most interesting interview with Cardinal Mercier well known as a staunch Belgian patriot and one who had suffered much at the hands of the Germans. He told us much of interest and on our leaving presented us each with an autograph photo of himself.

Lunch at Brussells – very expensive – 145 francs for a simple lunch for 4 – a very fine city and one that I shall again visit at an early date.

Monday 23rd December

Stayed in all day attending to correspondence. Pope took Charley to see Mons, Valenciennes, Arras, Cambrai and Le Cateau. Miserable wet day.

Tuesday 24th December

Attended parade of 5th & 6th Brigades in the morning and 7th Brigade in the afternoon. Presentation of medals by the Prince of Wales. He was accompanied by the Corps Commander. The Prince with Lord Hearston Corps Commander and Staff lunched at my HQrs. Presented to him Monsieur & Madame Bruask & children also the Burgomaster of Marcinelle. Several photos taken during the day by the official photographer. Dined at night with M. & Madam Brisall a brother of the owner of the house I am billeted in.
Entry.1192:
and accompanied by the first fall of snow this winter. A very light fall.

Two more D.Cs. awarded to Division for final fighting. One to Lt. Maxwell, M.C. and Bar, D.C.M. of 5th Brigade and one to 2/Lt. Ingram of
Entry.1193:
Bde. Took a piece of ribbon to each. Visited all Brigade HQrs., Artillery and Pioneers to wish all ranks the Compliments of the season.

Dinner at night to which we invited many guests. A total of 28 persons sat down to an excellent repast and afterwards we had some speech making, dancing and music. In conformity with custom, as host I had to have one dance with every lady capable of dancing – rather an ordeal considering I have not danced a step since leaving Australia. Guests seemed to thoroughly enjoy themselves.
Entry.1194: With Charley and Pope left Charleroi at 8.15 AM for Boulogne. Travelled via Mons and Tournai to Lille where I introduced Charley to Gens. White, Grant & Hamon. Lunched at Army HQrs. Afterwards met Gen. Hart of NZ Division returning from south of France to his Brigade and promised to pick him up on my return journey tomorrow. Also saw Gen. Eller of Tank Corps in Lille. Proceeded on via Menen, and Ghehurst to Ypres. Very desolate country, absolutely devastated ground nothing but shell holes, trees nothing but shattered stumps, villages effaced, concrete pill boxes smashed, derelict tanks in plenty, masses of wire and many isolated graves. Quite the most suitable spot to take a visitor who wishes to really see what war can mean. Ypres quite flat and absolutely ruined. Went on to Boulogne via Cassell, St. Omer & Desvres. Dined at Folkestone Hotel and took rooms at Hotel de Paris.
Entry.1195: Charley left by boat at 9.30 AM, having I am sure thoroughly enjoyed his leave. Returned to Lille via Hazebrouck, Bailleul and Armentieres. Bailleul in particularly is absolutely destroyed, so different now from the town we all remember in 1915-16-17 and early 18. At Lille again lunched at Army HQrs. Picked up Gen. Hart and brought him back to Charleroi via Valenciennes and Mons. He will go on from here by rail to Cologne. Arrived at my HQrs. at 8 PM Found Major MacCallum had departed for Australia. A very good officer and a gentleman – whose work has been of sterling value – I am sorry to lose him.
Entry.1196:
Gen. Hart with us all day. Cologne train late. He did not leave till midnight. About 250 officers and men left for discharge to Australia.

Attended to education and sports matters within the Division.
Entry.1197: Writing letters all day. Received report from 7th Brigade concerning officers conduct in Charleroi. At 8.30 PM visited several cafes and found everything quiet tho’ at one Cafe a few minutes before my arrival one of our officers had made himself objectionable. Conduct and deportment of men excellent.
Entry.1198:
In all day - writing letters, arranging details re Educational Scheme for University de Travail, Charleroi.

Loaned my car to my Host and Hostess for the purpose of taking them to visit Madame’s parents in Brussels. Capt. O ’Hara Wood accompanied them. They brought me back some glorious hothouse lilac blooms, and a fine plant in flower – red azalea. They have evidently discovered I am found of flowers.

Tuesday 31st December

With Pope visited Army HQrs. at Valenciennes. Saw Gen. Anderson M.G.G.S. who has been appointed to superintend the Staff College about to reopen at Camberley. Visited No. 2 Australian CCS at Ath. Saw Major Matthews who operated on my arm. He expressed his satisfaction at the progress made. Called at Mons and saw Lt. Godley commanding 22 nd Corps. Had a long talk on past and present associations. Returned to Marcinelle at 6 PM

Dinner party at night given by Messeur & Madame Brisall, our hosts. Quite a number of visitors were invited, and we had a very jolly evening finishing up at 2.30 AM on
Entry.1199:
I had to sing a number of songs.

The passing away of 1918 and the advent of 1919 eventuated under the pleasantest of conditions. We all look forward to a bright and happy New Year – The Year of World Peace.
